                      are wrappers around existing static StandardHandleState
                      and GetStdHandleFQFN methods on the StateManager class.

        /// <summary>
        /// Determine whether the Standard Error stream (STDERR) is redirected.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns>
        /// Return TRUE if the Standard Error stream is redirected. Otherwise,
        /// return FALSE.
        /// </returns>
        /// <remarks>
        /// In the unlikely event that GetCurrentProcess throws, the caller must
        /// catch it and shut down.
        /// </remarks>
        public static bool IsStdErrRedirected ( )
        {
            System.Diagnostics.Process ThisProcess = System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( );

            try
            {
                if ( ThisProcess.StandardError.BaseStream == null )
                {
                    return false;
                }
                else
                {
                    return true;
                }
            }
            catch ( InvalidOperationException )
            {
                return false;                                                   // The failure tells us what we want to know.
            }
        }   // IsStdErrRedirected

        /// <summary>
        /// Determine whether the Standard Input stream (STDERR) is redirected.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns>
        /// Return TRUE if the Standard Input stream is redirected. Otherwise,
        /// return FALSE.
        /// </returns>
        /// <remarks>
        /// In the unlikely event that GetCurrentProcess throws, the caller must
        /// catch it and shut down.
        /// </remarks>
        public static bool IsStdInpRedirected ( )
        {
            System.Diagnostics.Process ThisProcess = System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( );

            try
            {
                return ( ThisProcess.StandardInput.BaseStream == null );        // This either returns TRUE or throws an exception.
            }
            catch ( InvalidOperationException )
            {
                return false;                                                   // The failure tells us what we want to know.
            }
        }   // IsStdInpRedirected


        /// <summary>
        /// Determine whether the Standard Output stream (STDERR) is redirected.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns>
        /// Return TRUE if the Standard Output stream is redirected. Otherwise,
        /// return FALSE.
        /// </returns>
        /// <remarks>
        /// In the unlikely event that GetCurrentProcess throws, the caller must
        /// catch it and shut down.
        /// </remarks>
        public static bool IsStdOutRedirected ( )
        {
            System.Diagnostics.Process ThisProcess = System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( );

            #if SUPPRESS_TRACE
                // Suppress tracing.
            #else
                ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "Entering IsStdOutRedirected method." );
                ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     IsStdOutRedirected: ThisProcess object initialized" );
                System.Diagnostics.Debugger.Launch ( );
            #endif  // #if SUPPRESS_TRACE

            try
            {
                if ( ThisProcess.StandardOutput.BaseStream == null )
                {
                    #if SUPPRESS_TRACE
                        // Suppress tracing.
                    #else
                        ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     IsStdOutRedirected: ThisProcess.StandardOutput.BaseStream - returning FALSE" );
                    #endif  // #if SUPPRESS_TRACE

                    return false;
                }
                else
                {
                    #if SUPPRESS_TRACE
                        // Suppress tracing.
                    #else
                        ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     IsStdOutRedirected: ThisProcess.StandardOutput.BaseStream - returning TRUE" );
                    #endif  // #if SUPPRESS_TRACE

                    return true;
                }
            }
            catch ( InvalidOperationException )
            {
                #if SUPPRESS_TRACE
                    // Suppress tracing.
                #else
                    ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     IsStdOutRedirected: InvalidOperationException" );
                #endif  // #if SUPPRESS_TRACE

                return false;                                                   // The failure tells us what we want to know.
            }
        }   // IsStdOutRedirected

================================================================================
2016-03-28 15:16:04 - It appears that I've already implemented HandleBase in the
                      IsStdErrRedirected, IsStdInpRedirected, and
                      IsStdOutRedirected methods, although further refactoring
                      is in order.
================================================================================

        #region Static Utility Methods
        /// <summary>
        /// Determine whether the Standard Error stream (STDERR) is redirected.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns>
        /// Return TRUE if the Standard Error stream is redirected. Otherwise,
        /// return FALSE.
        /// </returns>
        /// <remarks>
        /// In the unlikely event that GetCurrentProcess throws, the caller must
        /// catch it and shut down.
        /// </remarks>
        public static bool IsStdErrRedirected ( )
        {
            System.Diagnostics.Process ThisProcess = System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( );

            try
            {
                if ( ThisProcess.StandardError.BaseStream == null )
                {
                    return false;
                }
                else
                {
                    return true;
                }
            }
            catch ( InvalidOperationException )
            {
                return false;                                                   // The failure tells us what we want to know.
            }
        }   // IsStdErrRedirected


        /// <summary>
        /// Determine whether the Standard Input stream (STDERR) is redirected.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns>
        /// Return TRUE if the Standard Input stream is redirected. Otherwise,
        /// return FALSE.
        /// </returns>
        /// <remarks>
        /// In the unlikely event that GetCurrentProcess throws, the caller must
        /// catch it and shut down.
        /// </remarks>
        public static bool IsStdInpRedirected ( )
        {
            System.Diagnostics.Process ThisProcess = System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( );

            try
            {
                return ( ThisProcess.StandardInput.BaseStream == null );        // This either returns TRUE or throws an exception.
            }
            catch ( InvalidOperationException )
            {
                return false;                                                   // The failure tells us what we want to know.
            }
        }   // IsStdInpRedirected


        /// <summary>
        /// Determine whether the Standard Output stream (STDERR) is redirected.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns>
        /// Return TRUE if the Standard Output stream is redirected. Otherwise,
        /// return FALSE.
        /// </returns>
        /// <remarks>
        /// In the unlikely event that GetCurrentProcess throws, the caller must
        /// catch it and shut down.
        /// </remarks>
        public static bool IsStdOutRedirected ( )
        {
            System.Diagnostics.Process ThisProcess = System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( );

            #if SUPPRESS_TRACE
                // Suppress tracing.
            #else
                ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "Entering IsStdOutRedirected method." );
                ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     IsStdOutRedirected: ThisProcess object initialized" );
                System.Diagnostics.Debugger.Launch ( );
            #endif  // #if SUPPRESS_TRACE

            try
            {
                if ( ThisProcess.StandardOutput.BaseStream == null )
                {
                    #if SUPPRESS_TRACE
                        // Suppress tracing.
                    #else
                        ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     IsStdOutRedirected: ThisProcess.StandardOutput.BaseStream - returning FALSE" );
                    #endif  // #if SUPPRESS_TRACE

                    return false;
                }
                else
                {
                    #if SUPPRESS_TRACE
                        // Suppress tracing.
                    #else
                        ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     IsStdOutRedirected: ThisProcess.StandardOutput.BaseStream - returning TRUE" );
                    #endif  // #if SUPPRESS_TRACE

                    return true;
                }
            }
            catch ( InvalidOperationException )
            {
                #if SUPPRESS_TRACE
                    // Suppress tracing.
                #else
                    ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     IsStdOutRedirected: InvalidOperationException" );
                #endif  // #if SUPPRESS_TRACE

                return false;                                                   // The failure tells us what we want to know.
            }
        }   // IsStdOutRedirected
        #endregion  // Static Utility Methods

[Obsolete("Use OutputOptions.EventLog.")]

        public enum AssemblyVersionRequest
        {
            /// <summary>
            /// This is functionally equivalent to specifying a constant value of
            /// ASSEMBLYVERSION_MAJOR_ONLY to the ToString method of a
            /// System.Version object, and is intended to do so through the
            /// GetAssemblyProductAndVersion instance method of this class.
            /// </summary>
            MajorOnly = 1,

            /// <summary>
            /// This is functionally equivalent to specifying a constant value of
            /// ASSEMBLYVERSION_MAJOR_AND_MINOR to the ToString method of a
            /// System.Version object, and is intended to do so through the
            /// GetAssemblyProductAndVersion instance method of this class.
            /// </summary>
            MajorAndMinor = 2,

            /// <summary>

s_dtmStartup = {2016-03-28 20:55:22}
s_dtmStartup = {2016-03-29 01:59:22}

        /// <summary>
        /// Evaluate whether a standard handle is attached to a console or
        /// redirected.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="penmStdHandle">
        /// Specify the ShsStandardHandle member that corresponds to the handle
        /// for which you wish to know whether it is attached or redirected.
        /// </param>
        /// <returns>
        /// If the function succeeds, the return value is either ShsAttached or
        /// ShsRedirected. Otherwise, there was an error, and you should call
        /// Marshal.GetLastWin32Error to determine exactly what happened. The
        /// singleton has a private property where the return value is stored.
        /// </returns>
        public static ShsHandleState StandardHandleState
            ( ShsStandardHandle penmStdHandle )
        {
            if ( IP6CUtilLib1.GetExeSubsystemID ( System.Reflection.Assembly.GetEntryAssembly ( ).Location ) == IP6CUtilLib1.PESubsystemID.IMAGE_SUBSYSTEM_WINDOWS_CUI )
            {
                switch ( ( ShsHandleState ) SafeNativeMethods.SHS_StandardHandleState ( ( uint ) penmStdHandle ) )
                {
                    case ShsHandleState.ShsAttached:
                        return ShsHandleState.ShsAttached;
                    case ShsHandleState.ShsRedirected:
                        return ShsHandleState.ShsRedirected;
                    case ShsHandleState.ShsUndeterminable:
                        s_dwLastError = Marshal.GetLastWin32Error ( );
                        return ShsHandleState.ShsUndeterminable;
                    default:
                        s_dwLastError = Marshal.GetLastWin32Error ( );
                        return ShsHandleState.ShsSystemError;
                }   // switch ( ( ShsHandleState ) SafeNativeMethods.SHS_StandardHandleState ( ( uint ) penmStdHandle ) )
            }   // TRUE (anticipated outcome) block, if ( IP6CUtilLib1.GetExeSubsystemID ( System.Reflection.Assembly.GetEntryAssembly ( ).Location ) == IP6CUtilLib1.PESubsystemID.IMAGE_SUBSYSTEM_WINDOWS_CUI )
            else
            {
                s_dwLastError = StateManager.UNSUPPORTED_EXE_SUBSYSTEM;
                return ShsHandleState.ShsSystemError;
            }   // FALSE (unanticipated outcome) block, if ( IP6CUtilLib1.GetExeSubsystemID ( System.Reflection.Assembly.GetEntryAssembly ( ).Location ) == IP6CUtilLib1.PESubsystemID.IMAGE_SUBSYSTEM_WINDOWS_CUI )
        }   // public static ShsHandleState StandardHandleState
        #endregion  // Public Static Methods

        penmStdHandle   ShsStdOut   WizardWrx.DLLServices2.StateManager.ShsStandardHandle

        /// <summary>
        /// This enumeration maps the value returned by SHS_StandardHandleState
        /// to a value that ideally indicates whether a handle is attached to a
        /// console or redirected, while the remaining codes indicate error
        /// conditions.
        /// </summary>
        public enum ShsHandleState
        {
            /// <summary>
            /// Value = 0 indicates that ShsStandardHandle is either undefined
            /// or out of range.
            /// </summary>
            ShsUndeterminable ,

            /// <summary>
            /// Value = 1 indicates that the handle corresponding to the value
            /// of ShsStandardHandle is attached a console.
            /// </summary>
            ShsAttached ,

            /// <summary>
            /// Value = 2 indicates that the handle corresponding to the value
            /// of ShsStandardHandle is redirected to a file or pipe.
            /// </summary>
            ShsRedirected ,

            /// <summary>
            /// Value = 3 indicates that an internal error occurred. Call
            /// Marshal.GetLastWin32Error to learn why.
            /// </summary>
            ShsSystemError
        } // ShsHandleState

        private static string BeautifyStandardHandleFQFN ( StateManager.ShsStandardHandle penmStdHandelID )
        {
            string strTempStandardHandleFQFN = StateManager.GetStdHandleFQFN ( penmStdHandelID );

        penmStdHandelID             ShSStdIn            WizardWrx.DLLServices2.StateManager.ShsStandardHandle
        strTempStandardHandleFQFN   ", NOT redirected"  string

            if ( strTempStandardHandleFQFN == WizardWrx.DLLServices2.Properties.Resources.MSG_CONSOLE_HAS_STD_HANDLE )
                return strTempStandardHandleFQFN;

        public static string AppendFullStopIfMissing ( string pstrInput )
        {
            const string FULL_STOP_AS_STRING = @".";

            if ( pstrInput.EndsWith ( FULL_STOP_AS_STRING ) )
                return pstrInput;
            else
                return string.Concat ( pstrInput , FULL_STOP_AS_STRING );
        }   // public static string AppendFullStopIfMissing

        pstrInput           "Console handle Standard Input (STDIN, a. k. a., Console.In) is attached to a console, NOT redirected"  string
        FULL_STOP_AS_STRING "."                                                                                                     string

                 End of Stack Trace
                 There are no further exceptions to report.    "

        internal static void PauseForPictures ( bool pfAppendLineFeed )
        {
            ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( string.Format ( "Entering PauseForPictures method with pfAppendLineFeed = {0}." , pfAppendLineFeed ) );

            if ( MessageInColor.IsStdOutRedirected ( ) )
            {   // Emit a line feed in lieu of the page break.
                ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     PauseForPictures: IsStdOutRedirected returned TRUE." );
                Console.WriteLine ( );
            }   // TRUE block, if ( MessageInColor.IsStdOutRedirected ( ) )
            else
            {   // Display a prompt, wait for input, clear the screen (and the I/O buffer), and emit a line feed if requested.
                ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite ( "     PauseForPictures: IsStdOutRedirected returned FALSE." );
                Console.Error.Write ( Properties.Resources.MSG_PHOTO_OP );
                Console.ReadLine ( );
                Console.Clear ( );

                if ( pfAppendLineFeed )
                {   // Caller requested a lone feed.
                    Console.WriteLine ( );
                }   // if ( pfAppendLineFeed )
            }   // FALSE block, if ( MessageInColor.IsStdOutRedirected ( ) )
        }   // private static void PauseForPictures

2016-03-29 19:40:46 - The next place where the debugger stops is in my
                      StateManager class.

                      The call stack makes it clear that the debugger let a lot

        /// <summary>
        /// Return the fully qualified name of the assembly that started the
        /// current process.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns>
        /// The return value is a string that contains the fully qualified name
        /// of the assembly that started the current process.
        /// </returns>
        ///<remarks>
        ///I made this a method so that it is computed as needed, even in a
        ///debugging session when the Visual Studio Hosting process runs all the
        ///property getters when an object is expanded in the locals or watch
        ///window.
        ///</remarks>
        public string GetAssemblyFQFN ( )
        {
            return System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( ).MainModule.FileName;
        }   // public string GetAssemblyFQFN

Locals:

+       $exception  {System.IO.IOException: The handle is invalid.

   at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError(Int32 errorCode, String maybeFullPath)
   at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError()
   at System.Console.Clear()
   at WizardWrx.DLLServices2.Util.SafeConsoleClear() in c:\Users\DAVE\Documents\Visual Studio 2013\Projects\WizardWrx_Libs\DLLServices2\DLLServices2\Util.cs:line 708}  System.Exception {System.IO.IOException}

        HResult -2147024890 int = 0x80070006

IOException uses the HRESULT COR_E_IO which has the value 0x80131620.

Source: "IOException Class"
        .NET Framework 2.0
        https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.io.ioexception(v=vs.80).aspx

+       this    {WizardWrx.DLLServices2.StateManager}   WizardWrx.DLLServices2.StateManager


-2,146,232,800

C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\8.1\Include\shared\winerror.h
//
// MessageId: E_HANDLE
//
// MessageText:
//
// Invalid handle
//
#define E_HANDLE                         _HRESULT_TYPEDEF_(0x80070006L)

The documentation vaguely implies that the HRESULT Is always COR_E_IO which has the value 0x80131620. However, I have discovered by experiment that the actual code is E_HANDLE (0x80070006L) when the exception is the result of an invalid handle, such as arises when Console.Clear() is called by a process whose standard output handle (Console.Out) is redirected.

That being so, I am writing a non-throwing wrapper around Console.Clear() that verifies the HRESULT to determine whether the exception is one that can be anticipated, or something else worthy of reporting.

Logged by me for https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/community/add/system.io.ioexception(v=vs.80).aspx


================================================================================
2016-03-29 20:28:15
================================================================================

System.IO.IOException was caught
  IsTransient=false
  Message=The handle is invalid.

  Source=mscorlib
  StackTrace:
       at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError(Int32 errorCode, String maybeFullPath)
       at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError()
       at System.Console.Clear()
       at WizardWrx.DLLServices2.Util.SafeConsoleClear() in c:\Users\DAVE\Documents\Visual Studio 2013\Projects\WizardWrx_Libs\DLLServices2\DLLServices2\Util.cs:line 710
  InnerException:

-       exIO    {System.IO.IOException: The handle is invalid.

        /// <summary>
        /// Format the stack trace to make it (hopefully) a tad easier to read.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="perrAnyKind">
        /// A reference to the entire exception is passed into the method, from
        /// which this routine extracts the stack trace.
        /// </param>
        /// <returns>
        /// The returned string contains the formatted stack trace.
        /// </returns>
        private static string FormatStackTrace ( Exception perrAnyKind )
        {
            if ( perrAnyKind == null )
                return string.Empty;
            else
                return string.Format (
                    WizardWrx.DLLServices2.Properties.Resources.STACKTRACE_TPL ,        // Format String
                    perrAnyKind.StackTrace ,                                            // Token index 0
                    Environment.NewLine );                                              // Token index 1
        }   // FormatStackTrace

        public static void SafeConsoleClear ( )
        {
            const uint E_HANDLE = 0x80070006;

            try
            {
                System.Diagnostics.Debugger.Launch ( );
                Console.Clear ( );
            }
            catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
            {
                try
                {
                    RichIOException exRichIO = ( RichIOException ) exIO;
                    var serializedParent = JsonConvert.SerializeObject ( exIO );
                    RichIOException c = JsonConvert.DeserializeObject<RichIOException> ( serializedParent );

                    if ( exRichIO != null )
                    {
                        if ( exRichIO.HRESULT != E_HANDLE )
                        {
                            StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exIO );
                        }   // if ( exRichIO.HRESULT != E_HANDLE )
                    }   // if ( exRichIO != null )
                }
                catch ( Exception exOtherNested )
                {   // Report the unexpected generic exception, then resume without clearing the console.
                    StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exOtherNested );
                }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
            }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
            catch ( Exception exOthers)
            {   // Report the unexpected generic exception, then resume without clearing the console.
                {
                    StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exOthers );
                }
            }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )

            return;
        }   // public static void SafeConsoleClear

            catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )

        E_HANDLE                0x80070006                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              uint

Reference:  "Json.net fails when trying to deserialize a class that inherits from Exception,"
            http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14186000/json-net-fails-when-trying-to-deserialize-a-class-that-inherits-from-exception#new-answer


@Lukasz Lysik is correct that the answer needs improving, but the best
improvement is, in fact, a simplification. I have confirmed by stepping through
code and saving the entire object and its properties that the only statement
that must be in GetObjectData is the first one, base.GetObjectData(info, context);
I have confirmed that every property gets populated, including the HRESULT, which
is protected in .NET 2.0. The same holds for the constructor, too.

2016-04-03 15:12:21 - Execution enters the catch block here, and the debugger
                      hides the disassembly.
================================================================================

            catch ( IOException exIO )
            {
                try
                {   // Serializing the IOException is the most straightforward way to cast it to a EnhancedIOException object.
                    EnhancedIOException exRichIO = new EnhancedIOException ( exIO );

                    if ( exRichIO != null )
                    {
                        if ( exRichIO.HRESULT != E_HANDLE )
                        {
                            StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exIO );
                        }   // if ( exRichIO.HRESULT != E_HANDLE )
                    }   // TRUE (anticipated outcome) block, if ( exRichIO != null )
                    else
                    {
                        throw new NullReferenceException ( Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_NULL_EnhancedIOException );
                    }   // FALSE (UNanticipated outcome) block, if ( exRichIO != null )
                }
                catch ( Exception exOtherNested )
                {   // Report the unexpected generic exception, then resume without clearing the console.
                    StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exOtherNested );
                }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
            }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
            catch ( Exception exOthers)
            {   // Report the unexpected generic exception, then resume without clearing the console.
                {
                    StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exOthers );
                }
            }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
        }   // public static void SafeConsoleClear

2016-04-03 15:39:24 - Advancing into the Catch block surfaces the exception, I
                      have a couple of noteworthy observations.

                      1 The documented HRESULT, 0x80131620, is the initial value
                        set on entry to the constructor, which suggests that it
                        is actually a default HRESULT, rather than the only
                        possible HRESULT.

                     2  There is a default message, "I/O error occurred."

                     3  A private string, _className, is initialized to the real
                        class name, WizardWrx.EnhancedIOException, although the
                        string appears to be well protected. I suspect that it
                        surfaces as the string returned by the GetType method,
                        which is inherited from System.Object.

================================================================================
2016-04-03 16:01:49 - Static JSON serializer method JsonConvert.SerializeObject
                      returns a string composed as follows.

                      1 Each property, whether public, protected, or private, is
                        represented by a comma-delimited substring.

                      2 Each property substring is composed of a pair of colon
                        delimited substrings.

                      3 Property names are always quoted, and the quotes appear
                        as escaped characters in the Visual Studio debugger.

                      4 Any value that is a System.String is quoted.

                      5 Empty arrays such as the Data property on this exception
                        are represented as a pair of empty French braces.

                      6 Uninitialized objects that the debugger would report as
                        null are reported by the unquoted literal, "null."

                      7 Integers are reported without formatting or quoting.

                      8 Strings, such as the StackTraceString, that contain
                        embedded newlines, are reported just as they would be in
                        any other circumstance.

                      9 Of particular interest is the ExceptionMethod value.

                        a.  The first character is a numeral 8, which may be the
                            number of bytes required by its argument list.

                        b.  Following the number is a substring.

                                \\nWinIOError\\nmscorlib

                            Following the first of two escaped backslashes is
                            nWinIOError, the local name of the faulting method.

                            Following the second backslash is the unqualifie
                            assembly name, nmscorlib.

                        c.  Immediately following the unqualified assembly name
                            is a comma, followed by the remainder of the fully
                            qualified assembly name, spearated by commas.

                        d.  Following the PublicKeyToken and another escaped
                            backslash is the following string.

                                nSystem.IO.__Error\\nVoid WinIOError(Int32, System.String)

                        I think this block is the serialization of a member that
                        surfaces as the TargetSite property of the exception.

                      HResult is signed, and I should probably surface it as
                      such.
================================================================================

            string serializedParent = JsonConvert.SerializeObject ( pexIOBase );

        serializedParent    "{\"ClassName\":\"System.IO.IOException\",\"Message\":\"The handle is invalid.\\r\\n\",\"Data\":{},\"InnerException\":null,\"HelpURL\":null,\"StackTraceString\":\"   at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError(Int32 errorCode, String maybeFullPath)\\r\\n   at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError()\\r\\n   at System.Console.Clear()\\r\\n   at WizardWrx.DLLServices2.Util.SafeConsoleClear() in c:\\\\Users\\\\DAVE\\\\Documents\\\\Visual Studio 2013\\\\Projects\\\\WizardWrx_Libs\\\\DLLServices2\\\\DLLServices2\\\\Util.cs:line 733\",\"RemoteStackTraceString\":null,\"RemoteStackIndex\":0,\"ExceptionMethod\":\"8\\nWinIOError\\nmscorlib, Version=2.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089\\nSystem.IO.__Error\\nVoid WinIOError(Int32, System.String)\",\"HResult\":-2147024890,\"Source\":\"mscorlib\"}"  string

================================================================================
2016-04-03 16:56:30 - Entering the public EnhancedIOException constructor.
================================================================================

        /// <summary>
        /// This method is required by the implicit ISerializable interface that
        /// permits a new instance to be constructed from a serialized instance
        /// of an System.IO.IOException Exception. This affords an effective way
        /// to derive a EnhancedIOException object from it.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="pexIOBase">
        /// This public constructor take a roundabout path, through a JSON
        /// serialization engine, to subclass the IOException thrown by a
        /// System.IO object.
        /// </param>
        public EnhancedIOException ( IOException pexIOBase )

-       pexIOBase                                           {
                                                                System.IO.IOException: The handle is invalid.

                                                                   at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError(Int32 errorCode, String maybeFullPath)

            catch ( IOException exIO )
            {
                try
                {   // Serializing the IOException is the most straightforward way to cast it to a EnhancedIOException object.
                    EnhancedIOException exRichIO = EnhancedIOException.SubclassIOException ( exIO );

                    if ( exRichIO != null )
                    {
                        if ( exRichIO.HRESULT != E_HANDLE )
                        {
                            StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exIO );
                        }   // if ( exRichIO.HRESULT != E_HANDLE )
                    }   // TRUE (anticipated outcome) block, if ( exRichIO != null )
                    else
                    {
                        throw new NullReferenceException ( Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_NULL_EnhancedIOException );
                    }   // FALSE (UNanticipated outcome) block, if ( exRichIO != null )
                }
                catch ( Exception exOtherNested )
                {   // Report the unexpected generic exception, then resume without clearing the console.
                    StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exOtherNested );
                }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
            }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
            catch ( Exception exOthers)
            {   // Report the unexpected generic exception, then resume without clearing the console.
                {
                    StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AppExceptionLogger.ReportException ( exOthers );
                }
            }   // catch ( System.IO.IOException exIO )
        }   // public static void SafeConsoleClear

2016-04-04 22:52:50 - Tiger-proof, and use this.
================================================================================

MethodImplAttribute(MethodImplOptions.NoInlining)]
public void SomeFunction(int i)
{
    // ...
    var a = Assembly.GetCallingAssembly();
    // ...
}

Source: Be careful when using GetCallingAssembly() and always use the release build for testing
        http://www.ticklishtechs.net/2010/03/04/be-careful-when-using-getcallingassembly-and-always-use-the-release-build-for-testing/


================================================================================
2016-04-05 22:17:45 - Following is the revised GetAssemblyFQFN method on class
                      WizardWrx.DLLServices2.StateManager. Since it implements
                      the Singleton pattern, methods that might otherwise be
                      statics are instance methods, and expensive ones stash the
                      result in a private instance variable.
================================================================================

        /// <summary>
        /// Return the fully qualified name of the assembly that started the
        /// current process.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns>
        /// The return value is a string that contains the fully qualified name
        /// of the assembly that started the current process.
        /// </returns>
        ///<remarks>
        /// I made this a method so that it is computed as needed, even in a
        /// debugging session when the Visual Studio Hosting process runs all
        /// the property getters when an object is expanded in the locals and
        /// watch windows.
        ///
        /// Version 6.0.381.32883 of this method called static method
        /// System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( ).MainModule.FileName
        /// to obtain the name of the main module. However, the first test of
        /// this library as a dependent exposed a moderately surprising, but not
        /// completely unexpected, side effect of having the Visual Studio
        /// Hosting Process enabled; it becomes the MainModule of the process.
        /// Worse yet, enumerating the ModulesCollection lists all the DLLs, but
        /// the expected MainModule, the main assembly under test, is nowhere to
        /// be found!
        ///
        /// Hence, beginning with version 6.0.382, this method reverts to a more
        /// reliable method, System.Reflection.Assembly.GetCallingAssembly(). To
        /// ensure that the optimizer doesn't inline it, although I find such an
        /// idea unlikely, the method is marked with a MethodImplAttribute,
        /// MethodImplOptions.NoInlining. Since I don't have a Using directive,
        /// both must be fully qualified by System.Runtime.CompilerServices.
        ///</remarks>
        ///<see cref="http://www.ticklishtechs.net/2010/03/04/be-careful-when-using-getcallingassembly-and-always-use-the-release-build-for-testing/"/>
        [System.Runtime.CompilerServices.MethodImplAttribute ( System.Runtime.CompilerServices.MethodImplOptions.NoInlining )]
        public string GetAssemblyFQFN ( )
        {
            return System.Reflection.Assembly.GetCallingAssembly ( ).Location;
        }   // public string GetAssemblyFQFN

        static StateManager ( )
        {
            s_SyncRoot = new SyncRoot ( LOCK_LBL );
            System.Diagnostics.Process sdpThisProcess = System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( );
            s_strInitialWorkingDirectoryName = sdpThisProcess.StartInfo.WorkingDirectory;
            s_fltConsoleMessageTimeFormat = new TimeDisplayFormatter ( );
            s_dtmStartup = sdpThisProcess.StartTime.ToUniversalTime ( );
            s_strMainAssemblyFQFN = System.Reflection.Assembly.GetCallingAssembly ( ).Location;
        }   // private static StateManage constructor

        s_strInitialWorkingDirectoryName    ""                                                                                                                                                      string
+       s_dtmStartup                        {2016-04-06 02:57:13}                                                                                                                                   System.DateTime
        s_strMainAssemblyFQFN               "C:\\Users\\DAVE\\Documents\\Visual Studio 2013\\Projects\\WizardWrx_Libs\\DLLServices2\\DLLServices2TestStand\\bin\\Debug\\WizardWrx.DLLServices2.dll" string
-       s_SyncRoot                          {WizardWrx.DLLServices2.SyncRoot}                                                                                                                       WizardWrx.DLLServices2.SyncRoot
                _strLabel                   "StateManager"                                                                                                                                          string
                Label                       "StateManager"                                                                                                                                          string


        [System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.SuppressMessage ( "Microsoft.Security" , "CA2122:DoNotIndirectlyExposeMethodsWithLinkDemands" ) ,
            System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.SuppressMessage ( "Microsoft.Interoperability" , "CA1404:CallGetLastErrorImmediatelyAfterPInvoke" )]
        private static void CreateOnFirstUse (
            SyncRoot plwlMaster ,
            ref StateManager ptsfThis )
        {
            lock ( plwlMaster )
                if ( ptsfThis == null )
                    ptsfThis = new StateManager ( );

            //  ----------------------------------------------------------------
            //  Following construction, perform the expensive property
            //  initializations that require unmanaged code.

        }   // public static uint GetExeSubsystem

        /// <summary>
        /// This method initializes all static members except the class, itself.
        /// </summary>
        static StateManager ( )
        {
            s_SyncRoot = new SyncRoot ( LOCK_LBL );
            System.Diagnostics.Process sdpThisProcess = System.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentProcess ( );

            //  ----------------------------------------------------------------
            //  The WorkingDirectory property of the StartInfo member of a
            //  System.Diagnostics.Process is empty unless the process starts
            //  via something like ShellExecute or a desktop shortcut that has a
            //  working directory. However, Environment.CurrentDirectory always
            //  has a value.
            //  ----------------------------------------------------------------

            s_strInitialWorkingDirectoryName = String.IsNullOrEmpty ( sdpThisProcess.StartInfo.WorkingDirectory )
                ? Environment.CurrentDirectory
                : sdpThisProcess.StartInfo.WorkingDirectory;
            s_fltConsoleMessageTimeFormat = new TimeDisplayFormatter ( );
            s_dtmStartup = sdpThisProcess.StartTime.ToUniversalTime ( );
        }   // private static StateManage constructor

        s_strInitialWorkingDirectoryName    "C:\\Users\\DAVE\\Documents\\Visual Studio 2013\\Projects\\WizardWrx_Libs\\DLLServices2\\DLLServices2TestStand\\bin\\Debug" string

        public static StateManager GetTheSingleInstance ( )
        {   // This call MUST be made by a public method, so that the calling assembly is set correctly.
            s_strMainAssemblyFQFN = System.Reflection.Assembly.GetCallingAssembly ( ).Location;
            CreateOnFirstUse (
                s_SyncRoot ,
                ref s_TheInstance );
            return s_TheInstance;
        }   // public static StateManager GetTheSingleInstance

                InitialWorkingDirectoryName         "C:\\Users\\DAVE\\Documents\\Visual Studio 2013\\Projects\\WizardWrx_Libs\\DLLServices2\\DLLServices2TestStand\\bin\\Debug" string
                ShowUTCTime                         true                                                                                                                        bool
        +       Static members


        public enum OutputOptions : byte
        {
            /// <summary>
            /// Show Method Name if TRUE.
            ///
            /// If the EventLog flag is also set, the method name is always
            /// written there.
            /// </summary>
            Method = 0x01 ,     // ON

            /// <summary>
            /// Show Source (Assembly) Name if TRUE.
            ///
            /// If the EventLog flag is also set, the originating assembly name
            /// is always written there.
            /// </summary>
            Source = 0x02 ,     // ON

            /// <summary>
            /// Show Stack Trace if TRUE.
            ///
            /// If the EventLog flag is also set, the stack trace is always
            /// written there.
            /// </summary>
            Stack = 0x04 ,      // ON

            /// <summary>
            /// Post to associated event log if TRUE.
            ///
            /// The value of the event source associated with the current
            /// ExceptionLogger instance determines which event log
            /// gets the message.
            ///
            /// WARNING: Unless your event source string is already registered,
            /// the application MUST run, one time only, with full administrator
            /// privileges AND use the event source to write a message into the
            /// Windows event log in order for it to be registered with Windows,
            /// which maps it to an event log.
            ///
            /// Once the event source string is registered, the application can
            /// use it to post messages to the event log in any Windows security
            /// context.
            /// </summary>
            EventLog = 0x08 ,   // ON

            /// <summary>
            /// Write message on STDOUT if TRUE and if the application has a
            /// working console.
            ///
            /// CAUTION: Although it is technically legal to set both
            /// StandardOutput and StandardError to TRUE, this can have the
            /// unwanted consequence of generating TWO copies of the message,
            /// unless STDOUT and/or STDERR is directed to a file or if both are
            /// redirected to the SAME file.
            /// </summary>
            StandardOutput = 0x10 , // OFF

            /// <summary>
            /// Write message on STDERR if TRUE and if the application has a
            /// working console.
            ///
            /// CAUTION: Although it is technically legal to set both
            /// StandardOutput and StandardError to TRUE, this can have the
            /// unwanted consequence of generating TWO copies of the message,
            /// unless STDOUT and/or STDERR is directed to a file or if both are
            /// redirected to the SAME file.
            /// </summary>
            StandardError = 0x20 ,  // OFF

            /// <summary>
            /// Undefined - reserved for future use
            /// </summary>
            Reserved1 = 0x40 ,      // OFF

            /// <summary>
            /// Undefined - reserved for future use
            /// </summary>
            Reserved2 = 0x80 ,      // OFF
        }  // OutputOptions

        private static void ShowKeAssemblyProperties ( System.Reflection.Assembly pmyLib )
        {
            System.Reflection.AssemblyName MyNameIs = System.Reflection.AssemblyName.GetAssemblyName ( pmyLib.Location );
            System.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo myVersionInfo = System.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo.GetVersionInfo ( pmyLib.Location );

            Console.WriteLine ( @"Selected properties of the library under test:{0}" , Environment.NewLine );

            Console.WriteLine ( @"    AssemblyFileBaseName = {0}" , System.IO.Path.GetFileNameWithoutExtension ( pmyLib.Location ) );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    VersionString        = {0}" , myVersionInfo.FileVersion );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    Culture              = {0}" , MyNameIs.CultureInfo.DisplayName );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    PublicKeyToken       = {0}" , Util.ByteArrayToHexDigitString ( MyNameIs.GetPublicKeyToken ( ) ) );

            Console.WriteLine ( @"    AssemblyGuidString   = {0}{1}" , WizardWrx.DLLServices2.Util.GetAssemblyGuidString ( pmyLib ) , Environment.NewLine );

            Console.WriteLine ( @"    ProductName          = {0}" , myVersionInfo.ProductName );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    LegalCopyright       = {0}" , myVersionInfo.LegalCopyright );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    LegalTrademarks      = {0}" , myVersionInfo.LegalTrademarks );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    CompanyName          = {0}" , myVersionInfo.CompanyName );

            Console.WriteLine ( @"    Description          = {0}" , myVersionInfo.FileDescription );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    Comments             = {0}{1}" , myVersionInfo.Comments , Environment.NewLine );

            Console.WriteLine ( @"    AssembyDirName       = {0}" , System.IO.Path.GetDirectoryName ( pmyLib.Location ) );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    AssemblyFileName     = {0}{1}" , System.IO.Path.GetFileName ( pmyLib.Location ) , Environment.NewLine );

            string strAssemblyFileFQFN = pmyLib.Location;
            System.IO.FileInfo fiLibraryFile = new System.IO.FileInfo ( strAssemblyFileFQFN );

            Console.WriteLine ( @"    File Creation Date   = {0} ({1} UTC)" , fiLibraryFile.CreationTime , fiLibraryFile.CreationTimeUtc );
            Console.WriteLine ( @"    File Modified Date   = {0} ({1} UTC)" , fiLibraryFile.LastWriteTime , fiLibraryFile.LastWriteTimeUtc );

            Console.WriteLine ( @"{0}End of selected properties{0}" , Environment.NewLine );
        }   // private static void ShowKeAssemblyProperties method

            a reference to a volatile field will not be treated as volatile
            C:\Users\DAVE\Documents\Visual Studio 2013\Projects\WizardWrx_Libs\DLLServices2\DLLServices2\ExceptionLogger.cs 867 21
            DLLServices2

'identifier': a reference to a volatile field will not be treated as volatile

A volatile field should not normally be passed using a ref or out parameter,
since it will not be treated as volatile within the scope of the function.
There are exceptions to this, such as when calling an interlocked API. As with
any warning, you may use the #pragma warning to disable this warning in those
rare cases where you are intentionally using a volatile field as a reference
parameter.

Source: Compiler Warning (level 1) CS0420
        https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/4bw5ewxy.aspx


#pragma warning Example

        public static ExceptionLogger GetTheSingleInstance ( )
        {
            if ( s_fSynchronizeFlagsNow )
                SyncNewFlagsWithOld ( _genTheOnlyInstance ,
                                      _genTheOnlyInstance._enmProcessSubsystem ,
                                      _genTheOnlyInstance._enmSubsystem ,
                                      _genTheOnlyInstance._enmEventLoggingState ,
                                      _genTheOnlyInstance._enmStackTraceDisposition );
            else
                s_fSynchronizeFlagsNow = true;

            return _genTheOnlyInstance;
        }   // public static ApplicationInstance GetTheSingleInstance (1 of 10)

==================================================================
Entering private static string ReformatExceptionMessage function:
==================================================================

        /// <summary>
        /// This private method beautifies the format of invalid argument
        /// exception reports.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="pexAnyKind">
        /// Reference to exception from which to extract and format its Message
        /// property.
        /// </param>
        /// <param name="pstrRoutineLabel">
        /// This string identifies the place in the source code where the
        /// exception was thrown.
        /// </param>
        /// <param name="pstrMessageTemplate">
        /// Format string, suitable for use with String.Format, from which the
        /// beautified message is constructed.
        /// </param>
        /// <returns>
        /// Beautified string, suitable for presentation on a console.
        /// </returns>
        private static string ReformatExceptionMessage (
            Exception pexAnyKind ,
            string pstrRoutineLabel ,
            string pstrMessageTemplate )
        {

+       pexAnyKind                  {
                                        System.ComponentModel.InvalidEnumArgumentException: The value of argument 'penmAssemblyVersionRequest' (0) is invalid for Enum type 'AssemblyVersionRequest'.
                                        Parameter name: penmAssemblyVersionRequest
                                           at WizardWrx.DLLServices2.StateManager.GetAssemblyProductAndVersion(AssemblyVersionRequest penmAssemblyVersionRequest) in c:\Users\DAVE\Documents\Visual Studio 2013\Projects\WizardWrx_Libs\DLLServices2\DLLServices2\StateManager.cs:line 650

==================================================================
Entering private static string GetMessageTruncationStart function:
==================================================================

        /// <summary>
        /// Look up the exception in the list of known exceptions and, if found,
        /// return a string that marks the point where the displayed message is
        /// to be truncated.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="pstrExceptionTypeName">
        /// This string contains the fully qualified type name of the exception,
        /// which is the key to an public Dictionary of strings that mark the
        /// point where the message should be truncated for display. Please see
        /// the Remarks section.
        /// </param>
        /// <returns>
        /// The return value, which may be the empty string, is text, such as a
        /// fixed label, that marks a point where the message supplied by the
        /// exception is truncated.
        /// </returns>
        /// <remarks>
        /// Typically, a message is truncated because we present the information
        /// in a more visually appealing and/or accessible format. Of the myriad
        /// exceptions exposed by the Base Class Library, not to mention custom
        /// exceptions derived from System.Exception, only a handful are "known"
        /// types that require attention.
        ///
        /// Messages from types that are unknown to this class (i. e., they have
        /// no entry in the s_dctKnowExceptionTypes dictionary, are preserved.
        ///
        /// This private method hides the processing required to cover for the
        /// unknown exception type.
        /// </remarks>
        private static string GetMessageTruncationStart ( string pstrExceptionTypeName )
        {
            if ( s_dctKnowExceptionTypes == null )
                return null;

            string rstrTruncateFromThisString = null;

            if ( s_dctKnowExceptionTypes.TryGetValue ( pstrExceptionTypeName , out rstrTruncateFromThisString ) )
                return rstrTruncateFromThisString;
            else
                return null;
        }   // private static string GetMessageTruncationStart

        pstrExceptionTypeName       "System.ComponentModel.InvalidEnumArgumentException"                                                                                                                                                                                                    string
        rstrTruncateFromThisString  null                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    string

==================================================================
Entering private static string StringTricks.ReplaceToken function:
==================================================================

        /// <summary>
        /// Given a string of text, another string of place holder text, which
        /// occurs zero or more times in the input string, return a string in
        /// which the place holder text is replaced with new text, supplied by
        /// the third argument.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="pstrToSearch">
        /// String to be searched and changed.
        /// </param>
        /// <param name="pstrToFind">
        /// String to be found and replaced.
        /// </param>
        /// <param name="strReplaceWith">
        /// String to substitute for all occurrences of string pstrToFind.
        /// </param>
        /// <returns>
        /// String pstrToSearch, with all ocurrances of string pstrToFind
        /// replaced with string strReplaceWith.
        /// </returns>
        /// <remarks>
        /// The Replace method of the String class behaves in a way that is
        /// counterintuitive to me, although this behavior is a direct
        /// consequence of, and consistent with, the characterization of strings
        /// as immutable objects.
        ///
        /// Unlike the Replace method of a String object, this static method
        /// returns a new String object.
        ///
        /// As a bonus, this function accepts string constants for all three
        /// arguments, although their most practical application is for the
        /// first two. This overcomes the second, and, in some ways, most
        /// serious, limitation of the Replace method on a String object, which
        /// is that string constants are devoid of a Replace method.
        ///
        /// One last dirty little secret; this method actually calls the Replace
        /// method on argument pstrToSearch, which is, in all cases, a first
        /// class String object, sporting a full ocmplement of properties and
        /// methods.
        ///
        /// Say it's syntactic sugar if you insist, but I'll keep using it in my
        /// code, and may eventually implement a version that takes references
        /// as arguments.
        /// </remarks>
        public static string ReplaceToken(
                string pstrToSearch,
                string pstrToFind,
                string strReplaceWith)
        {
            /*
            ----------------------------------------------------------------

            Author:         David A. Gray, Chief Wizard, WizardWrx,
                            http://www.wizardwrx.com/

            Date Written:   Wednesdsy, 31 October 2007

            History

            Date       Version Who Synopsis
            ----------- ------ --- ---------------------------------------------
            2007/10/31 1.1.1.0 DAG    Initial version, written in VB, in library
                                   WizardWrx.SharedUtl1.

            2008/01/29 1.0.2.0 DAG    Port to C#, in library WizardWrx.WebApp. The
                                   indicated version is the library version in
                                   which this function first appears.

            2008/06/03 2.0.6.4 DAG    Move from class UtlLib of library
                                   WizardWrx.WebApp into this library, which is
                                   a more logical home for it.

                                   The last version of WizardWrx.WebApp.UtlLib
                                   that exports this method is 2.3.3.6. From
                                   version 2.3.3.7 onwards, that library imports
                                   the method from this library, from which it
                                   already imports numerous other functions and
                                   constants.

            --------------------------------------------------------------------
            */

            /*
                Sanity check the argument list, to ensure that everything is
                something the Replace methos of a System.String object can
                handle gracefully.
            */

            if (pstrToSearch == null)
                return String.Empty;

            if (pstrToFind == null)
                return pstrToSearch;

            if (pstrToFind == String.Empty)
                return pstrToSearch;

            /*
                Call the Replace method on the input string, pstrToSearch, which
                returns a brand new string.
            */

            return pstrToSearch.Replace(
                pstrToFind,
                strReplaceWith);
        }   // function ReplaceToken

            //  ----------------------------------------------------------------
            //  Initialize the index of labels, which enables users to assign
            //  their own labels to the column headers.
            //  ----------------------------------------------------------------

            int intNSubstrings = this.PropertyStringDetails.ColumnCount;

            for ( int intCurrentColumn = SKIP_FIRST_COLUMN ; intCurrentColumn < intNSubstrings ; intCurrentColumn++ )
            {
                this.PropertyStringNames.Rows.Add ( new string [ ]
                {
                    this.PropertyStringDetails.Columns [ intCurrentColumn ].HeaderText ,
                    this.PropertyStringDetails.Columns [ intCurrentColumn ].Index.ToString ( ) ,
                    string.Empty
                } );
            }   // for ( int intCurrentColumn = SKIP_FIRST_COLUMN ; intCurrentColumn < intNSubstrings ; intCurrentColumn++ )

2016-04-19 16:00:12 - Save this code for reference before I delete this event
                      delegate.
================================================================================

        /// <summary>
        /// This event fires when a row loses focus.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="pobjSender">
        /// The sender argument is a reference to the control on whose behalf
        /// the event fired, cast to Object. To be useful, it must be cast to
        /// DataGridViewRow. Since I let the IDE generate this message stub,
        /// </param>
        /// <param name="peaEventArgsIgnored">
        /// Since this method ignores this specialized EventArgs type,
        /// DataGridViewCellEventArgs, it is named peaEventArgsIgnored.
        /// </param>
        private void        /// <summary>
        /// This event fires when a row loses focus.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="pobjSender">
        /// The sender argument is a reference to the control on whose behalf
        /// the event fired, cast to Object. To be useful, it must be cast to
        /// DataGridViewRow. Since I let the IDE generate this message stub,
        /// </param>
        /// <param name="peaEventArgsIgnored">
        /// Since this method ignores this specialized EventArgs type,
        /// DataGridViewCellEventArgs, it is named peaEventArgsIgnored.
        /// </param>
        private void PropertyStringNames_RowLeave ( object pobjSender , DataGridViewCellEventArgs peaEventArgsIgnored )
        {
            const int NEWNAME_COLUMN = 2;

            DataGridView dgrLeaving = ( DataGridView ) pobjSender;
            int intNRowsFilled = Util.INVALID_ORDINAL;

            for ( int intCurrentRow = Util.ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT ; intCurrentRow < dgrLeaving.RowCount ;intCurrentRow++ )
                if ( dgrLeaving.Rows [ intCurrentRow ].Cells [ NEWNAME_COLUMN ].FormattedValue != null )
                    intNRowsFilled++;

            cmdApplyNewLabels.Enabled = ( intNRowsFilled == dgrLeaving.RowCount );
        }   // PropertyStringNames_RowLeave

     ( object pobjSender , DataGridViewCellEventArgs peaEventArgsIgnored )
        {
            const int NEWNAME_COLUMN = 2;

            DataGridView dgrLeaving = ( DataGridView ) pobjSender;
            int intNRowsFilled = Util.INVALID_ORDINAL;

            for ( int intCurrentRow = Util.ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT ; intCurrentRow < dgrLeaving.RowCount ;intCurrentRow++ )
                if ( dgrLeaving.Rows [ intCurrentRow ].Cells [ NEWNAME_COLUMN ].FormattedValue != null )
                    intNRowsFilled++;

            cmdApplyNewLabels.Enabled = ( intNRowsFilled == dgrLeaving.RowCount );
        }   // PropertyStringNames_RowLeave

2016-04-23 09:13:13

System_CAPS_cautionCaution
Do not attempt to set focus from within the Enter, GotFocus, Leave, LostFocus,
Validating, or Validated event handlers. Doing so can cause your application or
the operating system to stop responding. For more information, see the
WM_KILLFOCUS topic.

The Enter and Leave events are suppressed by the Form class. The equivalent
events in the Form class are the Activated and Deactivate events. The Enter
and Leave events are hierarchical and will cascade up and down the parent
chain until the appropriate control is reached. For example, assume you have
a Form with two GroupBox controls, and each GroupBox control has one TextBox
control. When the caret is moved from one TextBox to the other, the Leave event
is raised for the TextBox and GroupBox, and the Enter event is raised for the
other GroupBox and TextBox.

Source: "Control.Leave Event," .NET Framework (curent version)
        https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.windows.forms.control.leave(v=vs.110).aspx

This enumeration has a FlagsAttribute attribute that allows a bitwise combination of its member values.

Source: "Keys Enumeration," .NET Framework (curent version)
        https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.windows.forms.keys(v=vs.110).aspx

2016-04-23 15:35:48 - Because it takes an argument, static method SetMaxTabIndex
                      is called upon to populate the s_aintKeyPartMaxima array.
================================================================================

            /// <summary>
            /// This method must be called before the first instance of
            /// ControlIndex is created.
            /// </summary>
            /// <param name="pfrmInThisForm">
            /// Pass the Form that was fed to the TabStopIndex constructor.
            /// </param>
            /// <remarks>
            /// This code cannot be implemented as a static constructor because
            /// the Form argument is required, and static constructors cannot
            /// take arguments.
            /// </remarks>
            public static void SetMaxTabIndex ( Form pfrmInThisForm )
            {
                const int KEYPART_TAB = 0;
                const int KEYPART_ROW = 1;
                const int KEYPART_COL = 2;
                const int KEYPARTS = 3;

                s_aintKeyPartMaxima = new int [ KEYPARTS ];

                s_aintKeyPartMaxima [ KEYPART_ROW ] = s_intMaxScreenHeight;
                s_aintKeyPartMaxima [ KEYPART_COL ] = s_intMaxScreenWidth;

                foreach ( Control ctrl in pfrmInThisForm.Controls )
                    if ( ctrl.TabIndex > s_aintKeyPartMaxima [ KEYPART_TAB ] )
                        s_aintKeyPartMaxima [ KEYPART_TAB ] = ctrl.TabIndex;
            }   // SetMaxTabIndex

================================================================================
2016-04-23 17:07:02 - ComputeMultiplersForSearching is a generic implementation
                      of the algorithm that I created and tested yesterday in
                      test project BigNumberExperiments.
================================================================================

        /// <summary>
        /// Given a list of maximum expected 32 bit integer values, return an
        /// array of 32 bit integer multipliers for deriving a single 64 bit
        /// integer to represent one of each in the single sort key required to
        /// ensure that the BinarySearch method on a generic list always finds
        /// exactly one match.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="paintMaxValues">
        /// The specified array must list maximum values in their intended order
        /// of appearance in the key derived by feeding this array, along with a
        /// separate array of actual values, to a companion static method,
        /// DeriveUnikeKeyForSearching.
        ///
        /// All values are expected to be positive integers.
        /// </param>
        /// <param name="penmNegativeMaxValueTreatment">
        /// Use a member of the NegativeMaxValueTreatment enumeration to specify
        /// how to treat negative integers in the pintMaxValues array.
        /// </param>
        /// <returns>
        /// Unless the input array is empty, the return value is an array of
        /// positive 32 bit integers. If the input array is either empty or a
        /// null reference, the returned array is empty.
        /// </returns>
        /// <exception cref="System.ComponentModel.InvalidEnumArgumentException">
        /// An System.ComponentModel.InvalidEnumArgumentException exception is
        /// thrown when the value of argument penmNegativeMaxValueTreatment is
        /// invalid.
        /// </exception>
        public static Int32 [ ] ComputeMultiplersForSearching (
            Int32 [ ] paintMaxValues ,
            NegativeMaxValueTreatment penmNegativeMaxValueTreatment )
        {
            const int DECIMAL_POWER = 10;
            const int MINIMUM_PERMITTED_MAX_VALUE = 0;
            const Int32 MULTIPLIER_FOR_RIGHTMOST_ITEM = 1;
            const Int32 WIDTH_FOR_ZERO = 1;

            Int32 [ ] raInt32;

            if ( paintMaxValues == null || paintMaxValues.Length == ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT )
            {
                raInt32 = new Int32 [ 0 ];
                return raInt32;
            }   // TRUE (degenerate case) block, if ( paintMaxValues == null || paintMaxValues.Length == ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT )
            else
            {
                int intNItems = paintMaxValues.Length;
                int intLastItem = intNItems - LAST_INDEX_FROM_COUNT;
                Int32 intLastMultipler = MULTIPLIER_FOR_RIGHTMOST_ITEM;

                raInt32 = new Int32 [ intNItems ];

                for ( int intThisPart = intLastItem ;
                          intThisPart >= ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT ;
                          intThisPart-- )
                {
                    if ( intThisPart < intLastItem )
                    {
                        if ( paintMaxValues [ intThisPart ] > MINIMUM_PERMITTED_MAX_VALUE )
                        {   // I expect most values to be positive integers.
                            intLastMultipler = intLastMultipler * ( int ) ( Math.Pow ( DECIMAL_POWER , MaxWidth ( paintMaxValues [ intThisPart ] ) ) );
                        }   // TRUE (Positive integers are always used as is.) block, if ( paintMaxValues [ intThisPart ] > MINIMUM_PERMITTED_MAX_VALUE )
                        else
                        {
                            switch ( penmNegativeMaxValueTreatment )
                            {
                                case NegativeMaxValueTreatment.SubstituteZero:
                                    intLastMultipler = intLastMultipler * ( int ) ( Math.Pow ( DECIMAL_POWER , WIDTH_FOR_ZERO ) );
                                    break;
                                case NegativeMaxValueTreatment.SubstituteAbsoluteValue:
                                    intLastMultipler = intLastMultipler * ( int ) ( Math.Pow ( DECIMAL_POWER , MaxWidth ( Math.Abs ( paintMaxValues [ intThisPart ] ) ) ) );
                                    break;
                                default:
                                    throw new System.ComponentModel.InvalidEnumArgumentException (
                                        "penmNegativeMaxValueTreatment" ,
                                        ( int ) penmNegativeMaxValueTreatment ,
                                        typeof ( NegativeMaxValueTreatment ) );
                            }   // switch ( penmNegativeMaxValueTreatment )
                        }   // FALSE (Negative integers require a bit more effort.) block, if ( paintMaxValues [ intThisPart ] > MINIMUM_PERMITTED_MAX_VALUE )
                    }   // if ( intThisPart < intLastItem )

                    //  --------------------------------------------------------
                    //  Multiplier insertion follows the IF block because the
                    //  multiplier for the first (rightmost) integer, being a
                    //  constant, is used to initialize intLastMultipler, which
                    //  happens before execution enters this loop.
                    //  --------------------------------------------------------

                    raInt32 [ intThisPart ] = intLastMultipler;
                }   // for ( int intThisPart = intLastItem ; intThisPart >= ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT ; intThisPart-- )

                return raInt32;
            }   // FALSE (anticipated case) block, if ( paintMaxValues == null || paintMaxValues.Length == ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT )
        }   // ComputeMultiplersForSearching

            /// <summary>
            /// Specify this property as the single search term of a
            /// BinarySearch against a collection of ControlIndexItem objects to
            /// ensure that the search finds exactly one match.
            /// </summary>
            /// <remarks>
            /// This property also drives the IComparable interface, a
            /// prerequisite for using BinarySearch, and greatly simplifies the
            /// implementations of the Equals and GetHashCode methods overrides.
            /// </remarks>
            protected Int64 UniqueKey
            {
                get
                {
                    return Util.DeriveUnikeKeyForSearching (
                        new int [ ]                         // Int32 [ ] paintInputValueSet
                        {
                            _intTabOrder ,                      // Segment 1 of 3 = Tab Index
                            _intRow ,                           // Segment 2 of 3 = Row (Y Coordinate)
                            _intColumn } ,                      // Segment 3 of 3 = Column (X Coordinate)
                        s_aintKeyPartMaxima ,               // Int32 [ ] paintMultiplierSet
                        Util.NegativeMaxValueTreatment.SubstituteZero );
                }   // UniqueKey property getter
            }   // Read-only UniqueKey property

protected void ChangeFocusIfExcluded ( )
        {
            const int ADJACENT_ITEM_IN_LIST = 1;

            ControlIndexItem cxiOverrideStop = null;

            int intTabStopOfActiveCtrl = _frmInThisForm.ActiveControl.TabIndex;

            if ( intTabStopOfActiveCtrl > _intTabStopJustLeft )

C:\Users\DAVE>compact /?
Displays or alters the compression of files on NTFS partitions.

COMPACT [/C | /U] [/S[:dir]] [/A] [/I] [/F] [/Q] [filename [...]]

  /C        Compresses the specified files.  Directories will be marked
            so that files added afterward will be compressed.
  /U        Uncompresses the specified files.  Directories will be marked
            so that files added afterward will not be compressed.
  /S        Performs the specified operation on files in the given
            directory and all subdirectories.  Default "dir" is the
            current directory.
  /A        Displays files with the hidden or system attributes.  These
            files are omitted by default.
  /I        Continues performing the specified operation even after errors
            have occurred.  By default, COMPACT stops when an error is
            encountered.
  /F        Forces the compress operation on all specified files, even
            those which are already compressed.  Already-compressed files
            are skipped by default.
  /Q        Reports only the most essential information.
  filename  Specifies a pattern, file, or directory.

  Used without parameters, COMPACT displays the compression state of
  the current directory and any files it contains. You may use multiple
  filenames and wildcards.  You must put spaces between multiple
  parameters.
